Hi, this is Emily from MinuteEarth.

Life and language evolve in many of the same
ways: a group splits, and over time, small

changes occur in genetic traits and particular
words.

Over more time, those differences get amplified,
eventually leading to new species and new
languages.

So by looking for similarities between different
species and different languages, we can trace
their origins and draw their family trees.
Except, sometimes, similarities can be misleading.

Take the similar-sounding words “emoticon”
and “emoji”: they describe similar things,
so you’d think they’d have similar origins.

But “emoticon” is a combination of the
English words “emotion” and “icon”,

while the word “emoji” combines the Japanese
words for picture and character; the two words

don’t hint at any hidden relationship between
English and Japanese.

Other coincidences include the English and
Mbabaram words for “dog”, the French and

German words for “Fire”, the Malay and
Greek words for “Eye”, and the Inuktitut
and Turkish words for “boat.”

And similarities in biology can also lead
us astray.

For example, biologists long thought that
these two birds must be sibling species, but

recent DNA testing suggests that they're not
even on the same evolutionary branch, and

may be less related than penguins and flamingos;
they evolved their bald headedness independently

- probably because they both pursued the same
carrion-eating lifestyle.

Similarly, these two look rodents look so
much alike that we named them both “porcupine,”

but in fact one of them is actually more closely
related to the super-soft chinchilla, while

the other is more closely related to the very
naked naked mole rat.

So, It turns out, if you are trying to determine
how two things are related, you can’t just

use one or two data points, even if they're
VERY pointy.
